One can't help to conclude when comparing the USA with Canada, that it would have been better for North America and the world if the colonies had remained part of the English crown instead of becoming independent.
 The USA is nowadays a country ruled by venal, easily influenced politicians by their cronies and lobbyists. Look not farther than the trillions of dollars of tax payers money used to save the sharks of Wall Street. Or the invasion of Iraq to obtain control of the oil reserves in Iraq as the US has done in Saudi Arabia. A country where individualism means every poor man, woman and child for him/herself. 
 If this forum is any indication of mainstream America, then it is populated by gun crazy paranoid chauvinistic, racists and Bible thumpers. The USA is a country of excesses and none of them is good.
 Canada instead is the model liberal country, with multicultural coexistence, calm procedural politics, superb social programs and cultural institutions, and essentially no tradition of political violence. They have a small number of excellent and cheap universities. The liberal government kept Canada out of Iraq, although Canadian troops are fighting and dying in Afghanistan.
 Issues that drive American nuts -national health insurance, for instance and abortion-are broadly and peaceably settled with minor smudges to the left or right.
 A liberal pacifist country is superior to a warmonger conservative one.

 Australia developed its own identity more cosmopolitan and in Sydney, a hedonistic life style.
 
 Today we drove to Watson Bay, had lunch at Doyle's on the ferry pier, watching kids playing on the beach. The weather was perfect, the harbour a colorful mosaic of sails. 
 
 Our son returned from a 3 week business trip to Vancouver, he liked the way they drive slowly and gentlemanly. Here we drive fast and dirty. It takes a while to accustom to Sydney driving. But he found Vancouver not a place he would trade for Sydney.
 
 I've to Montreal and Quebec and yes, they have areas which are charming but overall they are not really like France.

I don't mind a dull country, such as Switzerland but, a dull country such as Canada, no way Jose. Why not Canada? let me explain why:
 
 I have in front of me one of those Canadian government ads that appeared in The New Yorker in time for the G8 meeting. (Even the Queen made an appearance dressed in Canadian red).
 This ad below I will save for it is a beauty:
 
 "A good neighbour lends you a cup of sugar.
 A great neighbour supplies you with 1.4 million barrels of oil per day"And this is the best lying part:
 "And does it responsibly―with respect for the environment and a commitment to leadership in energy production through innovation ... blah blah..."
 
 What a bunch of unctuous, servile, subservient, sycophants Canadians are.
 
 Jesus H Christ!! the Canadians see an American butt and drop to their knees immediately. They are ideal neighbours, indeed,
 And when it comes to respect for the environment? Read this:
 
 The process of extracting oil from the vast Canadian sands is a messy one, and with enormous profits at stake, what chance does the environment have?
 TO MOST environmentalists, the oil sands of Alberta are "Canada's dirty secret". Described by Tar Sands 101 as "the largest industrial project in human history", the extraction of oil from bitumen (tar, in plain language) buried in the ground is blamed by them for causing air pollution, widespread deforestation and prodigious carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions as well as alcoholism, drug abuse and prostitution.
 The scale of what's going on around Fort McMurray in northeast Alberta is staggering. Vast areas of once heavily-wooded land have been taken over by the oil companies and either strip-mined by gigantic machinery - so large that it would crush an SUV without its operator even noticing - or deep-mined in situ with the use of steam to draw the bitumen from several hundred metres below ground.
 The Green Party's chairman, Senator Dan Boyle, recently called on our National Pensions Reserve Fund to support motions tabled by faith-based shareholder groups in Shell and BP on the issue. He said the extraction of oil from tar sands was "a particularly harmful, inefficient and greenhouse-gas-intensive method of producing fuel" and was "devastating for the local environment and indigenous communities".
 Neither Shell nor the other oil companies involved are making any apologies - because what they're doing is so profitable. "Over the period 2005-2009 average earnings for oil sands mining were around US$20 (15) per barrel, compared to . . . averages of around US$12 (9) per barrel," Shell said, adding that the oil sands contributed no less than US$31 billion (23.3billion) to its earnings over the same five-year period.
 
 Black gold in Alberta sands - The Irish Times - Sat, Apr 10, 2010
Fail to see how any of that makes Canada dull. Toronto is a seriously fun town and the American rockies got nothing on those north of the border.

Toronto a fun town? if you say so
